physDesc.p: Letter consists of four paages of typewriter text. Second page is blank, but cuould be the back of the first page. Fist page has no typed letter head, but includes the words "Monroe" and "Poerty" in handwiring at top right of the page above the date. The final page includes the letterhead "Amy Lowell, Heath Street, Brookline Mass.

div.p: I enclose a check for $60. to pay for my advertisement in your magazine. It brought me one answer which did not materialize, so that it hardly seems worth while to pursue advertising. I wish you would tell me if you ever received that paper on " Internationalism in Art" which I sent you the last week in June. I not only sent it, but telegraphed, and wrote to you from England, asking you if it had ever been received. I therefore ought at least to know whether you received the manuscript, or whether it was lost in the mails. Truly, Harriet, this is a bit unbusinesslike, for whether you received the manuscript or not, it seems very possible that you received either my telegram from Brookline before I sailed, or my letter from London in regard to it, and I do think you should have answered.
It is a little discouraging to wait so long before you publish my prose things. You ask me to Unknown number of lines missing

pb.p: of eight months before they get into print. The point of the article was to that it come out fairly near to Untermeyer’s and Alvord’s articles on the same subject in "Poetry and Drama,” and so furnish an answer and refutation to their premises. But you wait, and publish it when the people have forgotten all about the other things, and circumstances have entirely changed. I do not mean to find fault, but of course after waiting two months for a reply about the article, I am naturally a little upset. Also, do you not think in your advertisement in the Septmber number of "The Little Review" you might have included my "Forsaken" in the number of poems in the caption, “have you read?” It seems to me that it was worthy of being in included, considering that you included poems by Sandburg and Johns. However that may be, a child may gird at its mother, and it does not make any difference in long run, and " Poetry" is to a certain extent my mother, and I feel great loyalty and affection for it, and, it is needless to say, to you. I

I enclose a poem I wrote on the war, while I was in London. I do not include it in the war contest poems, because I know that it has no chance whatever of getting a prize, as no one else is writing in this metre in English, I am quite certain that you would know instantly who wrote it, and I feel certain that your vaunted Democracy is not so democratic as to give me a prize if you thought I did not need it, when other more deserving people would lose thereby. This is not democracy, but it is what most people call democracy, and I fearit is your kind. Therefore I spare you the horrid necessity of a choice.

This poem has been received enthusiastically by everyone to whom I heard read it, both in England and since I came home. I know it to be a good thing. I wish you would publish it in your November number with the other war poems, appending a note that the poem was not offered as one of the competing poems for the war prize.

I did not pay the sums you asked me to, to Ezra Pound, and to James Stephens. James Stephens
was in Paris, and it was quite impossible to reach him, as difficult as it would be for you, and everybody advised me against the attempt of trying to get money over to France from England. I told Ezra of your letter, and wished to give him the money at once, but he said he had already written to you to send it to him by Postal Order, and he was afraid there might be some mistake and he might be paid twice, so he preferred to wait until your remittance reached him. I am sorry not to have been of more use to you in this matter.

I am afraid the war will do a great deal of harm to poetry on the other side of the Ocean. A great many of the men there are planning to emigrate to America when the war is over. Several of the periodicals there have stopped. Now, if ever, is emphatically your chance.

Please let me hear from you as soon as possible. about the article. By the way, have you heard from Richard Aldington about the new "Imagistes Anthology" which we are bringing out, and which we are to bring out every year for five years? Ezra has left us, or we have left him for the moment. All the rest of us are in it, and it is only Ezra’s intense desire to always run everything entirely
